sect2.title: Introduction
sect2.para: With this integration, you can take advantage of source code management (SCM) systems like GitHub or GitLab to manage your packages sources. Then, you can integrate those sources with OBS to run different workflows, for instance, to build a package and report back the result to the SCM.
In the following sections, you will find the instructions to set up the integration between SCMs and OBS.

This chapter talks in GitHub jargon to simplify the text. As constantly mentioning all the names for the same things, e.g. Pull Requests/Merge Requests, is tiresome and confusing. However, every aspect has its correspondence in GitLab. Refer to for clarification of terminology.

sect2.title: Prerequisites
sect2.para: Before you start, you need to

listitem.para: have a repository on GitHub.
have a package on an OBS Instance.

sect2.title: Supported SCMs
sect2.para: We support the GitHub.com and GitLab.com instances.
We also support Self-Hosted instances from GitHub and GitLab. As long as the network connectivity works, OBS will be able to interact with that SCM.

sect2.title: Token Authentication
sect2.para: OBS and GitHub need to talk to each other. Tokens are the way to make this happen.

sect3.title: How to Authenticate OBS with SCMs
sect3.para: You have to create a GitHub personal access token. OBS is going to use it to talk to GitHub on your behalf.
The personal access token needs, at least, the following scopes assigned:

listitem.para: GitHub: repo
GitLab: api

sect3.para: Check GitHub’s and GitLab’s documentation to learn how.

sect3.title: How to Authenticate SCMs with OBS
sect3.para: You have to create an OBS workflow token. Github is going to use it to trigger actions on OBS on your behalf.

sect4.title: Create Token
sect4.para: You can create the OBS token via WebUI in Profile > Manage Your Tokens.
You can also use osc for this:
Example of response:
Make sure you replace long_ascii_salad with your real GitHub personal access token created in

warning.para: Don't forget to keep your token secret to prevent someone else from triggering operations in your name!

sect4.title: Regenerating Secrets and Deleting Tokens
sect4.para: If you suspect your OBS token secret was leaked, you can regenerate the secret or delete the whole token to secure it again:
Through the WebUI in Profile > Manage Your Tokens > Edit > Regenerate Token.
You can always delete your token via WebUI, in Profile > Manage Your Tokens, or with these commands:
sect4.screen: osc token # list all your tokens
osc token --delete $token_id # remove the token with the given id
sect4.para: Then you can create a new one as explained in and replace it wherever you use it.

sect2.title: Webhooks
sect2.para: Once OBS and GitHub are allowed to speak to each other, they can start talking via webhooks.

sect3.title: SCM Events
sect3.para: On a GitHub repository, events are happening all the time: a pull request is created, somebody pushes a commit, a pull request is merged etc. When you set up a webhook on GitHub, you can specify which events you are interested in. Only when those events happen, the webhook will be sent to OBS.
This is the list of SCM events supported by the existing workflows in OBS:

listitem.para: Pull requests
Pushes

sect3.para: Other SCMs like GitLab have similar behaviour; the main difference is how they name the events. Refer to the Equivalence Table for more details or read more about GitHub events and GitLab events.

sect3.title: How to Set Up a Webhook on Github
sect3.para: Go to the project you want to set the integration on, then under Settings > Webhooks.
You have to fill in the form with:

listitem.para: Payload URL: https://build.opensuse.org/trigger/workflow?id=12345. Replace 12345 with the OBS token numerical ID previously obtained.
Content type: application/json.
Secret: uvwxyz. Replace uvwxyz with the OBS token secret string previously obtained.
Enable SSL verification.
Let me select individual events: Pull requests, Pushes.

sect3.title: How to Set Up a Webhook on GitLab
sect3.para: Go to the project you want to set the integration on, under the Settings > Webhooks.
Fill in the following fields:

listitem.para: URL: https://build.opensuse.org/trigger/workflow?id=12345. Replace 12345 with the OBS token numerical ID previously obtained.
Secret Token: uvwxyz Replace uvwxyz with the OBS token secret string previously obtained.
Trigger: Merge request events, Push events, Tag push events.

sect2.title: OBS Workflows
sect2.para: A GitHub event occurs and OBS receives the corresponding webhook. Now is when the OBS workflows come into play.
A workflow is nothing else than a sequence of steps you want to perform in OBS. You can describe the steps to run in a YAML configuration file.
To do so, in the root directory of your GitHub repository, create a directory .obs which contains a file called workflows.yml.
The content of .obs/workflows.yml could look like this:rebuild_master: steps: - rebuild_package: project: home:Admin package: ctris filters: event: push
You can also define multiple workflows, each one needs an unique name. The following example contains two workflows: main_workflow and rebuild_master.
sect2.screen: main_workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: OBS:Server:Unstable source_package: obs-server target_project: OBS:Server:Unstable:CI filters: event: pull_request rebuild_master: steps: - rebuild_package: project: home:Admin package: ctris filters: event: push branches: only: - master
sect2.para: OBS assumes the configuration file is placed in your target branch and not in other branches or forks.

sect3.title: OBS Workflow Steps
sect3.para: We support the following steps (the keys used in the configuration file appears surrounded with parenthesis):

listitem.para: Branch a package in a project (branch_package).
Link a package to a project (link_package).
Configure repositories/architectures for a project (configure_repositories)
Rebuild a package (rebuild_package)

warning.para: The user the token belongs to needs to have permissions to branch a package, link packages, configure repositories/architectures and rebuild packages.

sect4.title: Branch a Package in a Project
sect4.para: Given we have a source package called ctris coming from a source project called games, and a target project called home:jane, this step will branch that package onto the target project, keeping in mind that:

listitem.para: With a pull request event, it will go to e.g.: home:jane:github:jane:ctris:PR-1/ctris. PR-1 being the pull request number.

With a push event for commits, it will go to e.g.: home:jane/ctris-66f2acfbded89a19935ee6d481b7cf2ab95427f6. 66f2acfbded89a19935ee6d481b7cf2ab95427f6 being the SHA of the latest commit that triggered the event.
With a push event for tags, it will go to e.g.: home:jane/ctris-release_1. release_1 being the name of the tag that triggered the event.

sect4.para: This is an example of a configuration file with a branch package step:
sect4.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: games source_package: ctris target_project: home:jane

sect4.title: Link a Package to a Project
sect4.para: The link package step is the equivalent of osc linkpac command.
Given a source project called devel, a source package called gcc, a target project called home:jane, and a GitHub fork called jane/gcc the step will link the package devel/gcc against:

listitem.para: home:jane:github:jane:gcc:PR-1/gcc for a pull request event. PR-1 being the pull request number.
home:jane/gcc-fae00a0ac0e5687343a60ae02bf60352002ab9aa with a push event for commits. fae00a0ac0e5687343a60ae02bf60352002ab9aa being the SHA of the latest commit that triggered the event.
home:jane/gcc-release_1 with a push event for tags. release_1 being the name of the tag that triggered the event.

sect4.para: This is an example of a configuration file with a link package step:
sect4.screen: workflow: steps: - link_package: source_project: devel source_package: gcc target_project: home:jane

sect4.title: Configure Repositories/Architectures for a Project
sect4.para: Given a project called home:jane, the step will configure a number of repositories and architectures for:

listitem.para: home:jane:jane_github:repo123:PR-1 when the event is a pull request. jane_github being the username/organization which owns the SCM repository. repo123 being the name of the SCM repository. PR-1 being the pull request number.
home:jane when the event is a commit or tag push.

sect4.para: Each repository needs:

listitem.para: a name, e.g.: openSUSE_Tumbleweed
a target project, e.g.: openSUSE:Factory
a target repository, e.g.: snapshot
a list of architectures to be defined for each repository. e.g.: x86_64 and i586

sect4.para: This is an example of a configuration file with a configure repositories step:
sect4.screen: workflow: steps: - configure_repositories: project: home:jane repositories: - name: openSUSE_Tumbleweed target_project: openSUSE:Factory target_repository: snapshot architectures: - x86_64 - i586 - name: openSUSE_Leap_15.2 target_project: openSUSE:Leap:15.2 target_repository: standard architectures: - x86_64

sect4.title: Rebuild a Package
sect4.para: Given a project called home:Admin and a package ctris, the step will rebuild the package home:Admin/ctris.
This is an example of a configuration file with a rebuild package step.
sect4.screen: workflow: steps: - rebuild_package: project: home:Admin package: ctris

sect3.title: Filters
sect3.para: You can customize when workflows run and what they report by declaring filters. There are two types:

listitem.para: Architectures and Repositories filters affect what we report back to GitHub.
Branch and Event filters will make workflows run or not for specific branches/events.

sect3.para: You can define them in the configuration file .obs/workflows.yml.
Here's an example with all filters:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: home:jane_doe source_package: ctris target_project: games filters: event: pull_request branches: only: - master - staging architectures: ignore: - s390x - ia64 repositories: only: - openSUSE_Tumbleweed

sect4.title: Filters Delimiters: only and ignore
sect4.para: Some steps can affect a group of elements (branches, architectures, etc.) You can use filter delimiters like only and ignore to specify which elements should be affected, or not, by the step.
The available filters delimiters are:

listitem.para: only: the step only affects the elements in the list.
ignore: the step affects all the elements except those in the list.

note.para: only has precedence over ignore, so if both are defined, ignore is not considered.

sect4.para: This is an example to run a workflow only for the target branches master:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - rebuild_package: project: games package: ctris filters: branches: only: - master

sect4.para: This is an example of a workflow reporting back to GitHub for all repositories, except the repository named openSUSE_Tumbleweed:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: games source_package: ctris target_project: home:jane_doe filters: repositories: ignore: - openSUSE_Tumbleweed

sect4.title: Event Filter
sect4.para: Setting an event filter will run the workflow only for those events. We already covered SCM Events here.
The available events filters are:

listitem.para: pull_request is for pull request events.
push is for push events related to commits.
tag_push is for push events related to tags.

sect4.para: The following is an example to run a workflow only for a pull request event:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: games source_package: ctris target_project: home:jane_doe filters: event: pull_request

sect4.title: Branches Filter
sect4.para: Matches target branches based on their names and runs a workflow only for those branches.
This is an example to run a workflow for all target branches, except master and final:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: home:jane_doe source_package: ctris target_project: games filters: branches: ignore: - master - final

sect4.para: Learn more about Filters Delimiters: only and ignore.

sect4.title: Architectures Filter
sect4.para: This filter matches architectures based on their names and report back to GitHub only for those architectures.
Example of a workflow reporting back to the GitHub only for architectures s390x and x86_64:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: home:jane_doe source_package: ctris target_project: games filters: architectures: only: - s390x - x86_64

sect4.para: Learn more about Filters Delimiters: only and ignore.

sect4.title: Repositories Filter
sect4.para: Matches repositories based on their names and report back to GitHub only for those repositories.
Example of a workflow reporting back to GitHub only for repositories openSUSE_Tumbleweed and CentOS_8:

para.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: home:jane_doe source_package: ctris target_project: games filters: repositories: only: - openSUSE_Tumbleweed - CentOS_8

sect4.para: Learn more about Filters Delimiters: only and ignore.

sect2.title: Status Reporting
sect2.para: Once all the steps in the workflow are done, OBS will report the build results back to GitHub. results back to GitHub.
OBS will show detailed package build status for each distribution and architecture you have set up in the configuration file.
Moreover, if your package builds several multibuild flavors, the status will have the flavor name appended to the package name:

figure.title: Build Status for Several Multibuild Flavors

note.para: Due to a limitation, the initial "pending" build status of packages with multibuild flavors is not reported. The build status for those flavors will however still be reported when the build finishes.

sect2.title: Workflow Runs
sect2.para: For every SCM event, OBS records the request and the response sent back to the SCM. These records are stored in OBS in the form of workflow runs. This helps with debugging workflows. If an error occurs in any of the workflow steps, the workflow run will record error messages.
Workflow runs can be found under the list of tokens.
You can check the status of the workflow run (running/fail/success) represented by icons.

sect2.title: OBS SCM Service
sect2.para: For some of the use cases, you might want the OBS package to get the sources from the pull request in GitHub.

For this, you can make use of the existing obs-service-tar_scm service. Your package should include a properly defined _service file. obs-service-tar_scm will automatically use the sources of the pull request that triggered it.

sect2.title: Test Build a Package For Every Pull Request on GitHub
sect2.para: You decide to manage your package sources from a GitHub repository. However, every time someone tries to add changes to your sources by opening a pull request, you need to verify that your package still builds for certain repositories and architectures in OBS. You can have the best of both worlds with the SCM/CI workflows integration in OBS.
You will need:

listitem.para: A project in OBS that you own, it will be the target project. Let's say: home:jane:playground.
A package in OBS that you want to test build, it will be the source package inside the source project. E.g.: GNOME:Factory/gnome-shell.
A repository in GitHub with the source code that will receive the pull requests, e.g.: https://github.com/GNOME/gnome-shell.
The required tokens to allow OBS and GitHub talk each other as explained in
The required webhooks so GitHub notifies OBS of any event as explained in

sect2.para: This is obviously a good candidate to use the OBS SCM Service.
There are two different strategies to do this: branching the package or linking to it.

sect3.title: Branch
sect3.para: If you decide to branch the package for the test build, the configuration file should be something like this:
sect3.screen: workflow: steps: - branch_package: source_project: GNOME:Factory source_package: gnome-shell target_project: home:jane:playground filters: event: pull_request
sect3.para: Whenever someone opens a new pull request in the repository, OBS will branch the source package onto the target project, trigger the build, and report the results in the pull request's status checks.
Keep in mind that, when OBS branches a package, it copies the repositories from the source project to the target project, so everything is ready to start building.
Once the pull request is accepted or closed, the branched package will be deleted.
Read how to set up the workflows and, specifically, the workflow steps.

sect3.title: Link and Configure Repositories
sect3.para: If you prefer to link the package for the test build, the configuration file should be something like this:
sect3.screen: workflow: steps: - link_package: source_project: GNOME:Factory source_package: gnome-shell target_project: home:jane:playground - configure_repositories: project: home:jane:playground repositories: - name: openSUSE_Tumbleweed target_project: openSUSE:Factory target_repository: snapshot architectures: - x86_64 - i586 - name: openSUSE_Leap_15.2 target_project: openSUSE:Leap:15.2 target_repository: standard architectures: - x86_64 filters: event: pull_request
sect3.para: Whenever someone opens a new pull request in the repository, OBS will create a target package linked to the source package.

Unlike the branching, in this case the repositories are not copied to the target project. That is why you need to set up the configure_repositories step giving you the flexibility to decide which repositories are you interested in.
Read how to set up the workflows and, specifically, the workflow steps.

sect2.title: Rebuild a Package for Every Change in a Branch
sect2.para: You have a test build set up and you want it to keep up to date with the new changes you add to the PR. One way to do it, is to configure a rebuild package step with a push event filter.
You need:

listitem.para: A project and package to test build. E.g.: home:jane/rust
A repository in GitHub with an opened PR. E.g.: https://github.com/jane/rust/pull/1
The required tokens to allow OBS and GitHub talk each other as explained in
The required webhooks so GitHub notifies OBS of any event as explained in
The source code synchronization setup with the OBS SCM Service.

sect2.para: The workflow configuration should be like this one:
sect2.screen: workflow: steps: - rebuild_package: project: home:jane package: rust filters: event: push
